DataElement.preferredName: Excision Colorectal Proximal Surgical Margin Surgical Margin Status ProximalMargin
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.:One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical._One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:A condition or state at a particular time._Status for absence or presence of margin

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Or Carcinoma In Situ Adenoma Absent At Proximal Surgical Margin

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Or Carcinoma In Situ Adenoma Absent At Proximal Surgical Margin
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.:Used to indicate position, location, or state.:Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.:A neoplasm arising from the epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated but non-invasive.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.:A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.

Concepts.definition: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
A malignant epithelial neoplasm which is confined to the epithelial layer without evidence of further tissue invasion.

A neoplasm arising from the epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated but non-invasive.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.
Not existing in a specified place at a specified time.
Used to indicate position, location, or state.
Situated nearest to a point of attachment or origin.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.

Concepts.definition: A neoplasm arising from the epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated but non-invasive.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.

A neoplasm arising from the epithelium.  It may be encapsulated or non-encapsulated but non-invasive.  The neoplastic epithelial cells may or may not display cellular atypia or dysplasia.  In the gastrointestinal tract, when dysplasia becomes severe it is sometimes called carcinoma in situ.  Representative examples are pituitary gland adenoma, follicular adenoma of the thyroid gland, and adenomas (or adenomatous polyps) of the gastrointestinal tract.

Used to indicate position, location, or state.

One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.:A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.
